Award.AwardTitle: Degenerate Elliptic Problems in Analysis and Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on qualitative properties of solutions to certain degenerate elliptic partial differential equations arising in different areas of mathematics. Some of the problems under investigation include fourth-order Monge-Ampere-type equations, nonlocal free boundary and phase transition problems, and degenerate fully nonlinear equations of concave type. One recurrent question is the smoothness of the solutions or their level sets and their behavior near singular points. For example, the project will investigate the smoothness of Lipschitz thin free boundaries and the dimensions of their singular sets, the boundary behavior of solutions of Monge-Ampere equations with degenerate boundary conditions, and the rigidity of level sets in nonlocal phase transitions.

Partial differential equations are used to describe a large variety of physical phenomena. At the same time, they contribute to the development of different branches of mathematics such as differential geometry, topology, probability, and algebraic geometry. In particular, Monge-Ampere equations occur naturally in the mathematical formulation of optimal transportation problems, many of them within the realm of our daily lives: traffic network planning in cities, internet traffic optimization, blood vessel branching in the human venous system, and meteorological fluid dynamics. Such equations also frequently turn up in other areas of mathematics, like Riemannian or conformal geometry. Nonlocal free boundary and phase transition problems appear in several areas of science, including fluid mechanics, plasma physics, and semiconductor theory. Thin free boundaries are relevant to our understanding of flame propagation and also in the propagation of surfaces of discontinuities. The final purpose of this project is to gain the correct perspective on interesting "degenerate" equations in order to be able to introduce innovative tools and methodologies to tackle them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Partial differential equations (PDEs) play a central role in the fields of applied and pure mathematics. They are used to describe mathematically most of the physical phenomenas encountered throughout the sciences.   
Although the PDE theory has been developing at a rapid pace over the past decades many important problems still remain to be solved. 
This project focused on qualitative properties of certain classes of PDEs which appearin diverse areas such as fluid dynamics, material sciences, financial mathematics, optimal transportation, control theory, geometry etc. 
The key outcomes of the project were published in specialized journals of high quality. The PI spread the knowledge acquired by giving seminar talks, by participating to conferences, and by mentoring graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.
Concrete progress on several basic problems in elliptic PDEs was achieved during the project. One such example is in the area of calculus of variations which is relevant to the theory of elasticity. The PI found a singular minimizer in physical dimensions for a purely convex energy functional, and this settled an important question in this field. 
For the Monge-Ampere equation, the PI developed the boundary regularity theory of solutions when the right hand side is discontinuous or degenerate. As a consequence, the smoothness of the eigenfunctions for the Monge-Ampere operator was established.
 The PI made some significant contributions to the area of free boundary problems. He obtained a higher order boundary Harnack inequality which has many applications to obstacle-type problems. Another question that was investigated is the regularity of the free boundary to the two-phase problem which appears in models of jets and cavities in fluid dynamics. Here the PI established the smoothness of the free boundary up to dimension 4. Finally the PI discovered some interesting features of solutions to nonlocal equations. It turns out that any continuous function can be approximated on a given compact set by a fractional harmonic function. The PI also found a generic discontinuous boundary behavior of minimal surfaces of nonlocal type.
